title: 106_hr5469
content: The Act titled "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2000" allows for judicial review of binational panel decisions under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. The "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2000" permits judicial review in the Court of International Trade within 30 days of a binational panel's determination under article 1904 of a US investigating authority decision. Allegations can be made regarding panel member misconduct, procedural departures, or exceeding authority. The "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2000" allows for judicial review in the Court of International Trade within 30 days of a binational panel's decision under article 1904. Appeals can be made if the panel exceeded its powers or if its actions affected the decision and integrity of the review process. In appeals of binational panel determinations, the Court of International Trade reviews the legal and factual analysis to determine if any actions described in the appeal have been established. If so, the original panel decision is vacated and judgment entered accordingly; if not, the original decision is affirmed. The Court of International Trade's decisions are binding on parties involved in matters before the panel. Exclusive jurisdiction resides with the Court if a notice of appeal is filed, and determinations are not subject to review by an extraordinary challenge committee. This section applies to all goods from NAFTA. The Court of International Trade's decisions are binding on parties involved in matters before the panel. This section applies to all goods from NAFTA countries subject to antidumping or countervailing duties in the United States. The Court of International Trade has exclusive jurisdiction over matters involving binational panel determinations. Section 516A of the Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to include a final determination of a binational panel convened under NAFTA. Section 516A of the Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to include a final determination of a binational panel convened under NAFTA, which involves a request for review pursuant to section 404A of the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. The amendments made by this Act apply to final determinations of binational panels under NAFTA published in the Federal Register after the enactment date.
